TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease presents
   from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s earlier today.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**]. Patient notes that he was doing all prescribed pulmonary
   hygiene, including inexsufflator and was at his baseline until early on
   day of [**Year (4 digits) **] when he felt acutely dyspneic and was noted to have an
   oxygen saturation in the 70s. (ED resident originally reported that
   patient's desaturation was measured on room air; however, patient
   cannot corraborate this information. Patient was discharged with
   instructions to remain on 4L supplemental oxygen at all times.)
   .
   Upon presentation to the ED: T 100.1, HR 76, BP 114/74, RR 22, O2Sat
   100% NRB. Patient was assessed as having a worsened CXR and was given
   prednisone 60 mg, albuterol and ipratropium neb, acetaminophen, Zosyn,
   and tobramycin. Vitals prior to transfer to the ICU were: HR 84, BP
   112/71, RR 14, O2Sat 98% NRB.
   .
   ROS:
   (+)ve: productive cough, dyspnea, back pain (baseline), abdominal pain
   (baseline)
   (-)ve: fever, chills, sweats, constipation, diarrhea, orthopnea,
   paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, sore throat, myalgias, coughing with
   meals or drinking
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
   1) CML s/p allogeneic stem cell transplant [**2121**] c/b GVHD
   2) Chronic graft vs host disease on immunosuppressants
   -has had chronic abdominal discomfort since transplant that is thought
   to be associated with GVHD
   -bronchiectasis and bronchiolitis obliterans related to GVHD of the
   lung
   3) h/o resistant pseudomonas ([**2124-6-8**]), ESBL E coli ([**2124-5-21**]),
   stenotrophomonas ([**2123-12-23**]) in sputum
   4) Linezolid for VRE bacteremia ([**2124-4-24**]) which he contracted during a
   hospitalization for cellulitis (see d/c summary [**2124-5-4**])
   5) Chronic RUQ pain since [**2113**] (?in addition to GVH-related pain)
   - work up unrevealing
   - on narcotics
   6) GERD w/ Barrett's esophagus
   7) Hypertension
   8) h/o pulmonary embolism in [**5-8**]; DVT [**12-27**]
   9) Compression fractures since the beginning of [**2122**] at T8, T9, T11,
   L1, and L3
   .
   MEDICATIONS: *per discharge on [**10-11**]/209*
   1. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: Forty (40) mg Subcutaneous Q12H
   (every 12 hours).
   2. Fentanyl 100 mcg/hr Patch 72 hr Sig: Two (2) patches Transdermal
   every seventy-two (72) hours.
   3. Lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Sig: One (1)
   Adhesive Patch, Medicated Topical DAILY (Daily): Apply to left side of
   back for 12 hours daily, then remove for 12 hours.
   4. Lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Sig: One (1)
   Adhesive Patch, Medicated Topical DAILY (Daily): Apply to right side of
   back for 12 hours daily, then remove for 12 hours.
   5. Methadone 5 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day)
   6. Methadone 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO QHS (once a day at
   bedtime)
   7. Pregabalin 75 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO QID (4 times a day)
   8. Morphine 30 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as
   needed for pain.
   9. Lorazepam 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: 1-2 Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as
   needed for anxiety.
   10. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1)
   Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).
   11. Amylase-Lipase-Protease 30,000-10,000- 30,000 unit Capsule, Delayed
   Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO three
   times a day: with meals.
   12. Multi-Vitamin W/Minerals Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a
   day.
   13. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO
   DAILY (Daily)
   14. Acyclovir 200 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO Q12H (every 12
   hours)
   15. Voriconazole 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12
   hours)
   16. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: Two (2) Tablet,
   Chewable PO three times a day
   17. Budesonide 3 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Capsule,
   Sust. Release 24 hr PO Q 8H (Every 8 Hours)
   18. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day)
   19. Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 80-400 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet
   PO DAILY (Daily)
   20. Polyethylene Glycol 3350 17 gram/dose Powder Sig: Seventeen (17)
   grams PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation
   21. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times
   a day)
   22. Mycophenolate Mofetil 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QAM once
   a day (in the morning)
   23. Mycophenolate Mofetil 250 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO QPM
   once a day (in the evening)
   24. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: 1-2 Tablets PO every six (6) hours
   as needed for fever or pain
   25. Combivent 18-103 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: Two (2) puffs
   Inhalation every 4-6 hours as needed for shortness of breath or
   wheezing
   26. Tobramycin 300 mg/5 mL Solution for Nebulization Sig: Five (5) ml
   Inhalation [**Hospital1 **] (2 times a day): 4 weeks on, 4 weeks off: started on
   [**10-7**] to end [**11-4**], to restart on [**12-3**]
   27. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) nebulization Sig: Three
   (3) ml Inhalation Q2H (every 2 hours) as needed for wheeze.
   28. Ondansetron 4 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea
   29. Heparin Flush (10 units/ml) 2 mL IV PRN line flush PICC, heparin
   dependent: Flush with 10mL Normal Saline followed by Heparin as above
   daily and PRN per lumen.
   30. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2
   times a day)
   31. Oxygen 2-4 liters/min by nasal cannula at all times
   32. Cough assist please dispense on mechanical insufflator-exsufflator
   cough assist use: at least twice daily settings: inspiratory pressure
   26, expiratory rpessure 32, pause dialt at 2, AUTO mode, pressures
   depend on seal of mask which is small
   33. Respiratory Therapy Requires frequent deep suctioning at least
   twice a day; [**Hospital1 **] use of acapella PEP device (at bedside); hourly use of
   incentive spirometer (at bedside); at lease twice daily use of
   insuffllator/exsufflator
   34. Diphenhydramine HCl 50 mg/mL Solution Sig: 12.5 mg Injection
   x1 PRN as needed for prior to Gammagard.
   35. Tylenol 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO x1 PRN as needed for
   prior to Gammagard.
   36. Gammagard S/D 10 gram Recon Soln Sig: as directed Intravenous once
   a month: next dose [**2124-10-17**]; premdicate with Tylenol 650mg PO and
   Benadryl 12.5mg IV.
   37. Prednisone 10 mg Tablets, Dose Pack Sig: Four (4) Tablets, Dose
   Pack PO once a day: Until [**10-11**], switch to 30 mg daily until [**10-19**]. Cont. Then, prednisone at 20mg daily indefinitely
   .
   ALLERGIES:
   NKDA
   .
   SOCIAL HISTORY: *from previous hospitalization*
   Lives with his sister and her husband. Previously worked as a
   manufacturing manager, is now on disability.
   Tobacco: quit > 12 years ago; 10 pack-year history
   EtoH: Denies
   Illicits: Denies
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY:
   Father with diabetes mellitus, BPH, alive at 85 yrs
   Mother with h/o breast cancer; d. TIAs and CVD at 75 yrs
   Sister with h/o breast cancer in her 50s, atrial fibrillation
   Two brothers with h/o melanoma
   .
   .
   PHYSICAL EXAM
   VITAL SIGNS:  T 96.9, HR 103, BP 110/68, RR 15, O2Sat 95% 5L NC
   GENERAL: Patient in fetal position on bed, appears fatigued
   HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No conjunctival pallor. No scleral
   icterus. PERRLA/EOMI. Oral mucosa dry with thick secretion, oropharynx
   benign
   NECK: Supple, no [**Doctor First Name **]
   CARDIAC: RR, nl S1, nl S2, nl M/R/G
   LUNGS: Scattered coarse crackles with rhonchi and expiratory pleural
   rub.
   ABDOMEN: +BS. distended. Tender across lower abdomen. No rebound.
   EXTREMITIES: BLE with 2+ pitting edema halfway up shins. Bilaterally 2+
   DP pulses. 2+ radial pulses.
   SKIN: Dry skin throughout and multiple wounds with scabs
   NEURO: A&Ox3. Somnolent with delayed response to direct questions. CN
   II-XII grossly intact. Preserved sensation throughout grossly. [**3-21**]
   strength UE And LE.
   PSYCH: Listens and responds to questions appropriately, pleasant
   .
   .
   LABS: (see below)
   .
   .
   PREVIOUS MICROBIOLOGY:
   .
   Aspirate [**2124-5-25**]:
   ESCHERICHIA COLI

   .
   In [**Location (un) 308**] prior discharge summary from [**2124-7-6**], discovered that

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease presents
   from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s earlier today.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and with multiple
   respiratory pahtogens in recent past. Most likely that patient
   developed a healthcare associated pneumonia given his recent prolonged
   hospitalizations. Last course of antibiotics for HAP was [**2124-9-28**] to
   [**2124-10-5**]. Possible that patient has developed resistance to this
   regimenn, though will treat empirically on past culture data until new
   sputum or BAL samples direct treatment. Aside from an uncomplicated
   bacterial pneumonia, possible that there is an associated pleural
   effusion given new CXR obtained in the ED. Rotation and positioning
   make intepretation difficult, so additional imaging with CT is
   reasonable. Must additionally give consideration to organisms likely to
   infect immunocompromised hosts; however, patient has been on
   prophylaxis with acyclovir, bactrim, voriconazole, and tobramycin.
   After initial treatment for baterial pneumonia and advanced imaging
   with CT, may need to consider BAL for collection of sample to guide
   treatment. As a final point, patient noted by nurse [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] to be
   without gag reflex and coughed after drinking water, despite multiple
   prior S/S evals, prudent to have patient screened again given poor
   pulmonary reserve and multiple [**Last Name (Titles) **] for hypoxia.
   - CT chest with contrast to determine if new CXR findings are
   atelectasis vs pneumonia vs effusion or some combination of several
   pathologies
   - Cover for healthcare associated pneumonia with vancomycin and zosyn
   (zosyn chosen with regard to prior sensitivities)
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction
   - Sputum culture
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Follow-up influenza screen from ED, though no need to further treat
   with oseltamivir given recent 7 day course from [**2124-10-2**] to
   [**2124-10-8**]
   - Possible need for bronch with BAL to direct treatment as above
   - Speech and swallow consult
   - NPO except medications until formal S/S eval
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:
   At previous [**Year (4 digits) **] patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60
   mg daily and had been titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain:
   Thought to be attributable to GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   Question if chronic respiratory acidosis related to large doses of
   opiates causing respiratory drive suppression and subsequent
   hypoventilation. Patient reporting [**3-26**] pain in abdomen and back at
   presentation.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT:
   Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events. Has been on enoxaparin
   40 mg Q12H for many months; however, a therapeutic dose of enoxaparin
   for this 70 kg gentleman would be 70 mg Q12H.
   - Research records to assess why on enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2124-10-14**] 10:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease presents
   from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s earlier today.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and with multiple
   respiratory pahtogens in recent past. Most likely that patient
   developed a healthcare associated pneumonia given his recent prolonged
   hospitalizations. Last course of antibiotics for HAP was [**2124-9-28**] to
   [**2124-10-5**]. Possible that patient has developed resistance to this
   regimenn, though will treat empirically on past culture data until new
   sputum or BAL samples direct treatment. Aside from an uncomplicated
   bacterial pneumonia, possible that there is an associated pleural
   effusion given new CXR obtained in the ED. Rotation and positioning
   make intepretation difficult, so additional imaging with CT is
   reasonable. Must additionally give consideration to organisms likely to
   infect immunocompromised hosts; however, patient has been on
   prophylaxis with acyclovir, bactrim, voriconazole, and tobramycin.
   After initial treatment for baterial pneumonia and advanced imaging
   with CT, may need to consider BAL for collection of sample to guide
   treatment. As a final point, patient noted by nurse [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] to be
   without gag reflex and coughed after drinking water, despite multiple
   prior S/S evals, prudent to have patient screened again given poor
   pulmonary reserve and multiple [**Last Name (Titles) **] for hypoxia.
   - CT chest with contrast to determine if new CXR findings are
   atelectasis vs pneumonia vs effusion or some combination of several
   pathologies
   - Cover for healthcare associated pneumonia with vancomycin and zosyn
   (zosyn chosen with regard to prior sensitivities)
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction
   - Sputum culture
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Follow-up influenza screen from ED, though no need to further treat
   with oseltamivir given recent 7 day course from [**2124-10-2**] to
   [**2124-10-8**]
   - Possible need for bronch with BAL to direct treatment as above
   - Speech and swallow consult
   - NPO except medications until formal S/S eval
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:
   At previous [**Year (4 digits) **] patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60
   mg daily and had been titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain:
   Thought to be attributable to GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   Question if chronic respiratory acidosis related to large doses of
   opiates causing respiratory drive suppression and subsequent
   hypoventilation. Patient reporting [**3-26**] pain in abdomen and back at
   presentation.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT:
   Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events. Has been on enoxaparin
   40 mg Q12H for many months; however, a therapeutic dose of enoxaparin
   for this 70 kg gentleman would be 70 mg Q12H.
   - Research records to assess why on enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, the following are the potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP): The patient has a history of bronchiolitis related to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and has been treated with antibiotics in the past. The development of HAP is possible, and empiric treatment with vancomycin and zosyn is warranted.
2. Pleural effusion: The new CXR suggests the possibility of a pleural effusion, which needs to be further evaluated with advanced imaging, such as a CT scan.
3. Respiratory acidosis: The patient's chronic respiratory acidosis may be exacerbated by the large doses of opiates, leading to hypoventilation.
4. Chronic GVHD: The patient's chronic GVHD is ongoing, and treatment with mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone needs to be continued.
5. Abdominal pain: The patient's chronic abdominal pain is thought to be related to GVHD, and further evaluation is needed to rule out other causes.
6. Back pain: The patient's back pain is also thought to be related to GVHD, and further evaluation is needed to rule out other causes.
7. Thrombotic events: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and continued prophylaxis with enoxaparin is necessary.
8. Opioid-induced respiratory depression: The patient's use of opioids may lead to respiratory depression, and close monitoring is necessary.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition may lead to deficiencies in various nutrients, which need to be addressed through nutritional supplementation.
10. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of GVHD and chronic abdominal pain may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation, diarrhea, or abdominal distension.

To address these potential complications, the plan includes:

1. Covering for HAP with vancomycin and zosyn.
2. Continuing prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassessing prior to planned taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
3. Continuing mycophenolate mofetil for chronic GVHD.
4. Continuing enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H for thrombotic prophylaxis.
5. Monitoring for respiratory acidosis and adjusting treatment as necessary.
6. Evaluating the patient's abdominal pain and back pain with further work-up and considering alternative diagnoses.
7. Providing nutritional support and addressing any nutritional deficiencies.
8. Monitoring for gastrointestinal complications and addressing them promptly if they occur.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presents from rehabilitation following an episode of hypoxia and is currently admitted to the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.5°F)
* Heart rate: 95 bpm (normal range: 90-103 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 111/63 mmHg (normal range: 76-117/63-87 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 12 inspirations per minute (normal range: 12-19 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 98% on 5L nasal cannula

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General: Ill appearing, appears fatigued
* HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic, no conjunctival pallor, no scleral icterus, PERRLA/EOMI
* Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy
* Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, normal S1, S2, and M/R/G sounds
* Lungs: Scattered coarse crackles with diffuse rhonchi
* Abdomen: Distended, tender across the lower abdomen, no rebound
* Extremities: Bilateral edema halfway up the shins, 2+ pitting edema, bilaterally 2+ DP pulses, 2+ radial pulses
* Skin: Dry skin throughout, multiple wounds with scabs

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 231 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* TCO2: 46 mmHg
* Blood glucose: 200 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 10.8/23.5/0.9, Ca++: 8.6 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Covering for healthcare-associated pneumonia with vancomycin and zosyn
* Continuing prednisone 30 mg daily
* Performing pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suction
* Trying to obtain a sputum culture
* Following up with blood cultures
* Following up with an influenza screen from the emergency department
* Ordering a speech and swallow consult
* Keeping the patient NPO except for medications until a formal swallow evaluation is performed

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Healthcare-associated pneumonia
* Atelectasis
* Cellulitis on the lower extremities
* Chronic GVHD-related abdominal pain and back pain
* Thrombotic events (DVT, PE)
* Infections related to the PICC line
* Nutritional deficiencies due to prolonged NPO status
* Delayed wound healing due to dry skin and scabs
* Respiratory failure due to chronic bronchiolitis-related respiratory disease

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a significant history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) who underwent Bone Marrow Transplantation (BMT) and has recently been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with pneumonia and hypoxemia.

The patient's condition is concerning due to the presence of recurrent collapse in the left lung, which may be related to recurrent mucus plugging in the setting of significant background hypoxemia. The patient's hypoxemia is not accompanied by significant evidence of new overwhelming infection, but vigilance is necessary for this possibility.

The patient is receiving treatment for hypoxemia, including mechanical insufflation-exufflation (MIE), flutter valve support, and Tobramycin inhalation. The patient is also receiving antibiotics, including Vancomycin and Zosyn, and will need to continue to receive these medications.

The patient has a history of CML-GVHD, which requires treatment with Mycophenolate Mofetil, Prednisone, and Bactrim. The patient is also experiencing pain, which is being managed with Lyrica, Methadone, Fentanyl Patch, and Lidocaine Patch.

The patient has cellulitis, which is being treated with Vancomycin and Zosyn. The patient will need to follow up with the doctor to monitor the progress of the infection and adjust treatment as necessary.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia, which may be related to the patient's underlying CML and GVHD. The patient's blood culture results are pending, and the doctor will need to consider antibiotic intervention based on these results.

The patient is at risk for aspiration due to his history of CML and GVHD, and the doctor will need to consider tracheostomy to aid in suctioning and coughing. The patient will also need to undergo speech and swallow evaluation to assess the risk of aspiration.

The patient's imaging studies show worsening left-sided opacities on chest X-ray, which may be related to the patient's pneumonia.

The patient's code status is full code, and the doctor will need to continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary to ensure the patient's safety and well-being.

Based on this information, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Recurrent collapse in the left lung, which may be related to recurrent mucus plugging in the setting of significant background hypoxemia.
2. Overwhelming infection, which may be treated with antibiotics.
3. CML-GVHD, which requires treatment with immunosuppressive medications.
4. Pain, which may be managed with pain medications.
5. Cellulitis, which requires treatment with antibiotics.
6. Aspiration, which may be managed with tracheostomy and speech and swallow evaluation.
7. Complications related to the patient's underlying CML and GVHD, such as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2021 and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). He is currently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to hypoxia and has been treated with various medications, including vancomycin, zosyn, and prednisone.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient has impaired lung function, with crackles bilaterally on lung exam and a SpO2 of 99%. He has a history of bronchiolitis-related GVHD and has been treated with multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm, and his blood pressure is within normal limits.
* Abdominal status: The patient has mild abdominal pain, which is thought to be attributable to GVHD.
* Skin integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, with erythema and warmth on the anterior aspect of his legs.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Healthcare-associated pneumonia: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and underlying respiratory conditions make him at risk for developing a healthcare-associated pneumonia.
2. Graft versus host disease (GVHD): The patient's GVHD is ongoing, and he may experience further complications, such as skin integrity issues, abdominal pain, and respiratory difficulties.
3. Chronic abdominal pain: The patient's chronic abdominal pain may worsen or become more severe, requiring further evaluation and treatment.
4. Chronic back pain: The patient's chronic back pain may worsen or become more severe, requiring further evaluation and treatment.
5. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient has a history of thrombotic events, and he may be at risk for developing a DVT or PE, especially with his current immobility.
6. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system makes him at risk for developing infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, or other bacterial or fungal infections.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding while on full anticoagulation with lovenox and his current use of medications such as vancomycin and zosyn may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and immobility may lead to nutritional deficiencies, including malnutrition, dehydration, or electrolyte imbalances.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is recommended that he continue to receive aggressive treatment for his GVHD, including prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, and enoxaparin. He should also continue to receive prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal medications to prevent healthcare-associated infections. Additionally, he should receive close monitoring for signs of worsening respiratory status, including hypoxia, and receive treatment for any potential respiratory complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating Graft Versus Host Disease (GVHD). He was admitted to the ICU from a rehabilitation facility after experiencing hypoxia. He has a history of bronchiolitis related to GVHD and has had multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He has been treated with a 7-day course of Tamiflu and is currently receiving antibiotics for a possible healthcare-associated pneumonia. He has also been experiencing fever, which is being treated empirically. He has chronic abdominal pain and back pain thought to be attributable to GVHD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Healthcare-associated pneumonia: The patient's history of bronchiolitis and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past increases his risk of developing a healthcare-associated pneumonia. The patient's recent course of Tamiflu and antibiotics may not have fully cleared the infection, and he may be at risk of developing a more severe infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and WBC trending down may indicate the presence of a bacterial infection, which could progress to sepsis if not treated promptly.
3. Chronic GVHD: The patient's history of chronic GVHD may lead to chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which could worsen if not managed effectively.
4. Thrombotic events: The patient's history of PE and DVT increases his risk of developing further thrombotic events, particularly with the continued use of enoxaparin.
5. Hypoxia: The patient's history of hypoxia and bronchiolitis increases his risk of developing further episodes of hypoxia, particularly if his respiratory status deteriorates.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding while on full anticoagulation with lovenox increases his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly with the continued use of enoxaparin.
7. Infection: The patient's history of multiple respiratory pathogens and chronic GVHD increases his risk of developing further infections, particularly if his immune system is compromised.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for healthcare-associated pneumonia and monitor for signs of worsening infection.
2. Continue empiric treatment for fever and monitor for signs of sepsis.
3. Manage chronic GVHD symptoms effectively to prevent worsening of abdominal pain and back pain.
4. Monitor for signs of thrombotic events and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor for signs of hypoxia and bronchiolitis and adjust respiratory support as necessary.
6. Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
7. Consider further testing to rule out underlying infections and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation and developed graft versus host disease (GVHD). The patient was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and was previously discharged to a high-level rehab facility. The patient has multiple medical conditions, including bronchiolitis related to GVHD, chronic abdominal pain, back pain, and a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The patient's current medical issues include:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and may have developed a healthcare-associated pneumonia. He is receiving empiric treatment with vancomycin and zosyn.
2. Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever, which may be due to atelectasis, healthcare-associated pneumonia, or cellulitis. He is receiving empiric treatment with vancomycin and zosyn.
3. Chronic GVHD: The patient has chronic GVHD, which is being managed with prednisone and mycophenolate mofetil.
4. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: The patient has chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which are thought to be attributable to GVHD. He is receiving pain management with fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches, and pregabalin.
5. Hx of PE, DVT: The patient has a history of PE and DVT, and is receiving prophylactic treatment with low-molecular-weight heparin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis and potential healthcare-associated pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and potential healthcare-associated pneumonia may lead to sepsis.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's chronic GVHD may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Thrombotic events: The patient's history of PE and DVT, as well as his current treatment with low-molecular-weight heparin, may lead to further thrombotic events.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may make him susceptible to infection.

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory status, fever, and abdominal pain, and to adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). The patient is currently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to hypoxia and is being treated for potential healthcare-associated pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has bronchiolitis-related GVHD and has a history of multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He is experiencing mild cough and increased work of breathing from baseline.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has no murmurs, and his blood pressure is within normal limits.
* Abdominal: The patient has +BS (blood in the stool) and is experiencing diffuse abdominal tenderness, which may be related to GVHD.
* Skin: The patient has impaired skin integrity and erythema anteriorly, which may be related to GVHD.

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Antibiotics: Vancomycin and Piperacillin-Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Pain management: Fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches, and pregabalin
* Immunosuppressive therapy: Mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone
* Anticoagulation therapy: Enoxaparin
* Prophylactic medications: Lansoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis and LMW heparin for DVT prophylaxis

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 231 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 14 mg/dL
* Sodium: 143 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.6 mEq/L
* Glucose: 200 mg/dL

The patient's microbiology results show:

* Respiratory viral antigen: Negative
* Sputum culture: Pending
* Blood culture: Pending

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Cover for healthcare-associated pneumonia with vancomycin and Zosyn
* Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily
* Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suction
* Follow-up sputum culture and blood cultures
* Continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn for fever
* Trend WBC counts and fever curves
* Continue mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone for GVHD
* Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches, and pregabalin for pain management
* Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H for anticoagulation therapy

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Healthcare-associated pneumonia
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Thrombotic events
* Skin breakdown and infection
* Chronic GVHD-related complications

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjusting his treatment plan as necessary to prevent these complications and ensure his optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with severe respiratory failure, chronic obstructive lung disease, and significant impairment in chest wall function. He has been admitted to the ICU for ongoing respiratory support.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 79 bpm (normal range: 63-82 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 114/65 mmHg (normal range: 98/56-136/83 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 16 inspirations per minute (normal range: 11-20 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 88% (normal range: 95-100%)
* SpO2: 88% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient has been receiving various medications, including:

* Voriconazole
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Vancomycin
* Enoxaparin (Lovenox)
* Lansoprazole (Prevacid)
* Metadone/Lidocaine/Fentanyl for pain control

The patient has also been receiving respiratory support, including nasal cannula oxygen and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.4 K/uL (normal range: 4.6-11.1 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL (normal range: 13.5-17.5 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 231 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Total CO2: 46 mmHg (normal range: 32-44 mmHg)
* Glucose: 200 mg/dL (normal range: 70-110 mg/dL)

The patient's imaging studies show no evidence of recurrent collapse.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient will require ongoing respiratory support to maintain airspace patency and clear secretions.
* Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): The patient will require treatment with MMF and acyclovir.
* Pain control: The patient will require treatment with metadone, lidocaine, and fentanyl.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further compromise of his lung function and increased risk of pneumonia.
* Graft-versus-host disease: The patient's GVHD can worsen, leading to further damage to his skin, liver, and other organs.
* Pain: The patient's pain can worsen, leading to further discomfort and potentially compromising his respiratory function.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and skin infections.
* Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to his low platelet count.
* Renal failure: The patient is at risk for developing renal failure due to his low creatinine levels.

In conclusion, the patient is a high-risk patient who requires ongoing respiratory support, treatment for GVHD, and pain control. He is at risk for developing various medical complications, including respiratory failure, GVHD, pain, infection, bleeding, and renal failure.

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 4 of an 8 day course. (Vanc needs ID approval
   today)
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction today; MIE being brought over
   - F/u final sputum cx, viral cx
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Will have discussion with patient and family regarding goals of care
   because if he decompensates and needs intubation, it is very likely
   that he would need subsequent trach which he does not want
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant, complicated by graft versus host disease (GVHD). He was admitted to the ICU due to hypoxia and is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F), heart rate of 70 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/74 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 96% on aerosol-cool oxygen delivery device. He is sleeping and easily arousable, with a normal cardiac exam, crackles bilaterally with decreased breath sounds throughout, and faint wheezing.

The patient has a history of chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which is thought to be attributable to GVHD. He is also at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to his prior thrombotic events.

The patient is being treated with vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), and enoxaparin for his HAP. He is also receiving prednisone for GVHD and chronic abdominal pain and back pain. His medications include mycophenolate mofetil, fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches, and pregabalin.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and HAP increase his risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's HAP and fever increase his risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Graft versus host disease (GVHD): The patient's GVHD can lead to chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which can impact his quality of life.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's history of thrombotic events increases his risk of developing DVT and PE, which can be life-threatening.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state increases his risk of developing infections, which can be life-threatening.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. The patient's treatment plan should be tailored to his specific needs and risk factors, and regular assessments should be performed to monitor his response to treatment and adjust his plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) after allogeneic stem cell transplant. He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and was found to have bronchiolitis-related GVHD with multiple respiratory pathogens. He is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient has a low-grade fever and is being empirically treated for possible atelectasis, HAP, or cellulitis on his left leg.

The patient's physical examination reveals crackles in both lungs, and his laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and neutrophils. His respiratory viral antigen screen is negative, and his sputum Gram stain shows budding yeast and gram-positive rods.

The patient's plan includes continuing HAP coverage with vancomycin and Zosyn, as well as prednisone for GVHD. He will also undergo pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, and deep suction. Follow-up sputum and viral cultures are pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's bronchiolitis-related GVHD and HAP increase the risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate the presence of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.

6. Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): The patient's GVHD may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and death.
7. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: The patient's chronic GVHD may cause chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which could impact his quality of life.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's chronic GVHD and use of corticosteroids may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which could impact his overall health and well-being.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and Graft-Versus-Host Disease (GVHD) who was re-admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with recurrent hypoxemia at a rehabilitation facility. He has chronic respiratory compromise due to COPD and chest wall restriction, as well as bronchiolitis, which is driving some of the obstruction. The patient has been actively participating in therapeutic interventions and has had good capacity to maintain secretion clearance.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 123/75 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on nasal cannula. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 5.4, hemoglobin of 8.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 205 K/uL.

The patient's physical examination is notable for diminished breath sounds and rhonchorous sounds in the lungs, as well as right lower extremity edema. His abdominal examination is normal, and his neurological examination is intact.

The patient's medical history includes CML, GVHD, and chronic respiratory compromise. He has been taking various medications, including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and enoxaparin.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's chronic respiratory compromise and bronchiolitis make him susceptible to pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and chronic respiratory compromise put him at risk for respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's immunocompromised state and chronic respiratory compromise make him susceptible to sepsis.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's chronic respiratory compromise and use of anticoagulants put him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Wound infection: The patient's impaired skin integrity and chronic respiratory compromise make him susceptible to wound infection.
6. Chronic pain: The patient's chronic pain from compression fractures and GVHD may lead to decreased mobility and increased risk of complications.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's chronic respiratory compromise and impaired gut function may lead to nutritional deficiencies.
8. Increased risk of bleeding: The patient's chronic respiratory compromise and use of anticoagulants put him at risk for increased bleeding.

ICU care plan:

1. Continue oxygen therapy to maintain oxygen saturation above 90%.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide aggressive pulmonary toilet as needed.
3. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
4. Provide pain management for the patient's chronic pain.
5. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide enteral nutrition as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's wound status and provide wound care as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Consider transfer to a rehabilitation facility for further management and therapy.

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 5 of an 8 day course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction today; MIE being brought over
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Will have discussion with patient and family regarding goals of care
   because if he decompensates and needs intubation, it is very likely
   that he would need subsequent trach which he does not want
   - address question of possible trach for improved ventilation at night
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation in 2021 and developed graft versus host disease (GVHD). He was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) from a rehabilitation facility due to hypoxia and is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy via a nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 97%. His respiratory support includes mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suction.

The patient's physical examination is notable for wheezes in his breath sounds, tender abdomen with diffuse tenderness in all four quadrants, and right and left lower extremity edema to the mid-calf level.

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 109 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 200 mg/dL
* Other lab results include:
	+ PT/PTT/INR: 10.3/25.0/0.8
	+ Differential: Neuts 88.0%, Band 2.0%, Lymph 5.0%, Mono 3.0%, Eos 1.0%
	+ Calcium: 8.2 mg/dL
	+ Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
	+ Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to underlying bronchiolitis and GVHD
* Pneumonia-related complications, such as sepsis or respiratory failure
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation, due to GVHD
* Thrombotic events, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), given the patient's history of PE and DVT
* Infection-related complications, such as sepsis or organ failure, given the patient's low-grade fever and erythema on the left lower extremity
* Tracheostomy-related complications, such as bleeding or infection, if the patient requires intubation

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing treatment for HAP with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure and adjusting oxygen therapy as needed
* Continuing prednisone therapy for GVHD and tapering down to 20 mg daily on October 19th
* Continuing mycophenolate mofetil therapy for GVHD
* Managing chronic abdominal pain and back pain with ongoing pain management
* Continuing enoxaparin therapy for thromboprophylaxis
* Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting empiric treatment as needed

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting his plan of care accordingly to prevent potential complications and optimize his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented to the ICU from a rehabilitation facility with an episode of hypoxia to the 70s. The patient is currently receiving treatment for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and has a history of chronic abdominal pain and back pain thought to be attributable to GVHD. He also has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Current Status:

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate of 68 beats per minute, blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His respiratory status is labored, with diminished breath sounds and scattered wheezes throughout. He has a soft abdomen with bowel sounds present, but is tender to palpation in all four quadrants.

Lab Results:

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 5.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.9 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 109 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 15 mg/dL
* Sodium (Na): 140 mEq/L
* Potassium (K): 4.4 mEq/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 8.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 2.6 mg/dL

Potential Medical Complications:

Based on the patient's current status and medical history, potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's labored breathing and diminished breath sounds may indicate respiratory failure, which could worsen if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and WBC count may indicate the presence of an underlying infection, which could progress to sepsis if not treated promptly.
3. Graft versus host disease (GVHD): The patient's history of GVHD and current symptoms of abdominal pain and back pain may indicate ongoing GVHD, which could worsen if not managed properly.
4. Thrombotic events: The patient's history of PE and DVT may indicate an increased risk of future thrombotic events, which could worsen if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient's current treatment for HAP and history of multiple respiratory pathogens in the past may indicate an increased risk of future infections, which could worsen if not managed properly.

Plan:

The patient will continue to receive treatment for HAP and GVHD, and will be monitored closely for signs of respiratory failure, sepsis, and thrombotic events. He will also receive prophylactic treatment for stress ulcers and deep vein thrombosis. The patient's pain management will be continued and adjusted as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant, complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented from a rehabilitation facility with an episode of hypoxia and was admitted to the ICU.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient continues to experience labored breathing, which is his baseline at the rehabilitation facility. He has wheezes in his breath sounds and diminished lung sounds. He is receiving treatment for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn).
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is somewhat controlled with his current pain regimen.
* Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever of 100.1°F, which could represent atelectasis, HAP, or cellulitis on his left leg given the erythema and warmth.
* Hemodynamics: The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 68 beats per minute, blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97% on nasal cannula.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 5.4 K/μL, hemoglobin is 8.9 g/dL, and platelet count is 109 K/μL. His blood cultures are pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's labored breathing and wheezes in his breath sounds may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and stable white blood cell count may indicate a low-grade infection, which could progress to sepsis if left untreated.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's abdominal pain and use of pain medications may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Venous thromboembolism: The patient's history of pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) increases his risk of developing further venous thromboembolic events.
* Infection: The patient's history of GVHD and immunosuppressive therapy increases his risk of developing infections, particularly fungal and viral infections.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue treatment for HAP with vancomycin and Zosyn.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if his condition worsens.
* Continue empiric treatment for fever with vancomycin and Zosyn.
* Trend the patient's white blood cell count and fever curves to monitor for signs of infection.
* Continue immunosuppressive therapy with mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone.
* Monitor the patient's abdominal pain and adjust his pain regimen as needed.
* Continue anticoagulation therapy with enoxaparin to prevent venous thromboembolism.
* Consider further imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to evaluate the patient's abdominal pain and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-inch tall, 69.3 kg male who has been admitted to the ICU with labored breathing and abdominal pain. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, and his cardiovascular examination is normal. His respiratory examination shows wheezes and diminished breath sounds. His abdominal examination is soft, with bowel sounds present, and tender to palpation in all four quadrants.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, and his calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medication regimen includes vancomycin, acyclovir, voriconazole, and piperacillin/tazobactam, which were started on the previous day. He is also receiving enoxaparin for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis and lansoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that may arise based on this information include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's labored breathing and wheezes on respiratory examination may indicate a risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and elevated BUN and creatinine levels may indicate a risk of sepsis.
3. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's receipt of enoxaparin for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis and his elevated BUN and creatinine levels may indicate a risk of deep vein thrombosis.
4. Stress ulcer: The patient's receipt of lansoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis and his abdominal pain may indicate a risk of stress ulcer.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels may indicate a risk of electrolyte imbalance.
6. Renal failure: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels may indicate a risk of renal failure.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's receipt of multiple medications, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient's respiratory status be closely monitored, and that his medication regimen be reassessed to ensure that it is not contributing to any potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) who has been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure. He has a history of obstructive lung disease, chest wall restriction with vertebral fractures and kyphosis, and a small area of left lower lobe (LLL) collapse. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has been on various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and pain control medications. He has a PICC line and is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to his underlying lung disease, chest wall restriction, and vertebral fractures. There is a risk of further deterioration in his respiratory status, which could lead to respiratory arrest or failure.
2. Infection: Although the patient does not have evidence of ongoing active infection at this time, there is still a risk of developing an infection, particularly in the respiratory tract, given his underlying immunocompromised state.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and his history of chest wall restriction increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Septic shock: The patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory failure make him susceptible to septic shock, particularly if he develops an infection.
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's use of mechanical ventilation increases his risk of developing VAP, which could lead to further respiratory failure and complications.
6. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient's PICC line increases his risk of developing a CLABSI, which could lead to sepsis and other complications.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and his immobility increase his risk of developing a DVT, which could lead to pulmonary embolism and other complications.
8. Renal insufficiency: The patient's use of medications, such as antibiotics and antifungals, and his underlying kidney disease increase his risk of developing renal insufficiency.

Based on the patient's condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory status, infection risk, and other complications.

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
    #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 6 of an 8 day course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment.  Given that he is still not able to be weaned to bipap,
   consider keeping at this dose.
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction daily
   - Trial of Bipap at 10/5 today; has used in the past with favorable
   response
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Per outpatient pulmonologist, trach is unlikely to improve his
   functional status and may worsen his ability to cough; will hold off on
   trach unless patient needs to be intubated
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant, complicated by graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented to the ICU with an episode of hypoxia to the 70s and was discharged to a high-level rehabilitation facility on [**2124-10-11**].

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including bronchiolitis related to GVHD, history of pneumonia, and chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which are thought to be attributable to GVHD.

The patient is currently being treated for Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) with Vancomycin and Zosyn, and is also receiving treatment for fever, which may represent atelectasis, HAP, or cellulitis on the left lower extremity. He has a low-grade fever of 100.1°F and erythema and warmth on the left lower extremity.

The patient is also receiving treatment for chronic GVHD, including mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone, and has a history of chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which is thought to be attributable to GVHD.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may worsen if he is not able to be weaned off the ventilator or if he develops further respiratory complications.
2. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing further infections, including sepsis, which could worsen his condition.
3. GVHD: The patient's GVHD may worsen, leading to further complications, including chronic abdominal pain and back pain.
4. Thrombotic events: The patient has a history of thrombotic events, including pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis, and may be at risk for further thrombotic events.
5. Pain management: The patient is receiving treatment for chronic pain, but may require further management to control his symptoms.
6. Nutritional issues: The patient may have nutritional issues, including malnutrition, which could worsen his condition.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient may develop gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which could worsen his condition.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that he continue to receive treatment for HAP, fever, and chronic GVHD, and that his condition be closely monitored for any signs of worsening hypoxia, infection, GVHD, thrombotic events, pain, nutritional issues, or gastrointestinal complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented from rehabilitation with an episode of hypoxia to the 70s. The patient is currently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for management of Hypoxia, Fever, and Chronic Abdominal and Back Pain.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics for Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) and is currently on a 6-day course of Vancomycin and Zosyn. He has also been prescribed prednisone for GVHD and chronic pain management. The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. His blood cultures are pending, and he has been started on empiric treatment for HAP.

The patient's skin integrity is impaired, and he has chronic pain requiring management. He also has a history of Pulmonary Embolism (PE) and Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and is currently on Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin (LMW Heparin) prophylaxis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past may lead to worsening hypoxia.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated liver enzymes may indicate an ongoing infection, which could worsen his condition.
3. Chronic Abdominal and Back Pain: The patient's chronic pain may require ongoing management to prevent further complications.
4. Thrombotic Events: The patient's history of PE and DVT may increase his risk of future thrombotic events.
5. Graft Versus Host Disease (GVHD): The patient's GVHD may worsen his condition and require ongoing management.
6. Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate CKD, which could worsen his condition.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory pathogens may lead to respiratory failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic treatment for HAP and monitor for signs of infection.
2. Manage the patient's chronic pain with ongoing medication and therapy.
3. Monitor the patient's skin integrity and provide wound care as needed.
4. Continue prophylaxis for DVT and PE.
5. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust treatment as needed.
6. Consider consultation with a pulmonologist to optimize respiratory care.
7. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust treatment as needed.

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
    #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 6 of an 8 day course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment.  Given that he is still not able to be weaned to bipap,
   consider keeping at this dose.
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction daily
   - Trial of Bipap at 10/5 today; has used in the past with favorable
   response
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Per outpatient pulmonologist, trach is unlikely to improve his
   functional status and may worsen his ability to cough; will hold off on
   trach unless patient needs to be intubated
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicated by graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented to the ICU with hypoxia and was treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and is currently being weaned off it. He has also been experiencing fever, chronic abdominal pain, and back pain, which are thought to be related to GVHD. The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of respiratory failure if the patient is not weaned off the ventilator successfully.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and WBC count may indicate a bacterial infection, which could lead to sepsis if not treated promptly and effectively.
3. Thrombosis: The patient's history of PE and DVT increases his risk of developing thrombotic complications, including pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's chronic abdominal pain and use of anticoagulant medications increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and history of GVHD make him more susceptible to infections, including bacterial, fungal, and viral infections.
6. Organ dysfunction: The patient's chronic GVHD and history of CML treatment may lead to organ dysfunction, including liver, kidney, or lung dysfunction.
7. Bleeding complications: The patient's use of anticoagulant medications and history of thrombotic events increase his risk of bleeding complications, including hemorrhagic stroke or gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Metabolic complications: The patient's use of corticosteroids and immunosuppressive medications may lead to metabolic complications, including hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and electrolyte imbalances.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition require close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and significant obstructive lung disease, currently experiencing hypercarbic respiratory failure with complications of spinal fractures. The patient's recent course has been complicated by significant secretions, and strategies for clearance are a significant focus at this time.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 97.6°F (36.4°C)
* Heart rate: 63 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 127/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Thin
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, distant
* Respiratory/Chest: Symmetric expansion, dull percussion, wheezes, diminished breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, protuberant
* Extremities: Right and left lower extremity edema: Trace
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, movement and tone not assessed

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 5.4 K/uL
* Platelet count: 94 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 12 mg/dL
* Glucose: 200 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.7 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.5 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Continue with nasal-tracheal suctioning, alb/atrovent inhaler, and flutter valve to facilitate secretion clearance
* Hold BIPAP due to increase in secretion clearance and hypoxemia, and re-trial once secretions decrease
* Screen for possible rehabilitation placement and keep in ICU for now
* Manage pain with fentanyl, lidocaine, MSO4, Lyrica, and methadone
* Continue GVHD treatment with Cellcept, prednisone, and budesonide
* Monitor for and manage potential complications such as DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Respiratory failure due to persistent hypercarbia and inadequate secretion clearance
* Increased risk of aspiration pneumonia due to decreased lung function and increased secretions
* Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and anticoagulation therapy
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to underlying immunocompromise and potential bacterial or fungal infections
* Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer and anticoagulation therapy
* Development of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease due to prolonged critical illness and potential nephrotoxic medications.

   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction daily

   - Per outpatient pulmonologist, trach is unlikely to improve his
   functional status and may worsen his ability to cough; will hold off on

   WBC stable and remains afebrile.

   - F/u Blood cultures

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following information can be summarized:

* The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicated by graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
* The patient presented with hypoxia and was admitted to the ICU.
* The patient has been treated for Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn).
* The patient has impaired skin integrity, pain control issues, and hypoxemia.
* The patient has a history of CML, GVHD, and chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which is thought to be attributable to GVHD.
* The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure due to hypoxemia and HAP
* Sepsis due to HAP and other respiratory pathogens
* Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) exacerbation
* Thrombotic events, including PE and DVT
* Infections, including cellulitis and atelectasis
* Chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which can lead to decreased mobility and increased risk of complications
* Impaired skin integrity, which can lead to wound infections and delayed healing
* Pain control issues, which can lead to decreased mobility and increased risk of complications

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, the following plan of care can be recommended:

* Continue treatment for HAP with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and sepsis
* Continue prophylaxis for DVT with lovenox
* Monitor for signs of GVHD exacerbation and adjust treatment as necessary
* Continue pain control medications and adjust as necessary
* Monitor for signs of infections, including cellulitis and atelectasis
* Continue deep suctioning and pulmonary hygiene measures to prevent atelectasis and promote lung expansion
* Monitor for signs of impaired skin integrity and adjust treatment as necessary
* Continue monitoring of WBC counts and fever curves to monitor for signs of infection
* Continue mycophenolate mofetil and prednisone taper to manage GVHD
* Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H to prevent thrombotic events.
